name: Moderator Kathy
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who saw Margaret Court win the U.S. Open, and Kathy Dickensheets of Pittsburgh, who is looking forward to seeing if Serena can slam her way into history by winning more Grand Slam titles.

Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

My partner and I notice that Margaret Court has won more Grand Slam titles than Serena Williams when they were both in their early 30's. Steffi Graf is also the youngest, but has a competitive number of Grand Slam titles with the older players. Martina Navratilova, from 25-30, continuously won titles but has plateaued with her winnings. 

We think the graph is telling us that regardless of age, individuals can succeed in an intense setting. However, we also can recognize that age can be a hindrance to one's athletic career, seen by the decline in winnings by some, but not all, of the older athletes. 

We are still curious about how age plays a role in athletes' success because some of the competitors seem to be affected by it while others do not. Is there a difference in their preparation?

"Is Age a Factor? Not for these Grand Slam Winners."

name: James Bond
comment info:
I notice that Steffetti qualified for a Grand Slam Tournament at only thirteen which is an impressive feat. I wonder if these women ever competed in the same tournament against each other which would create a plateau for one line and an increase in titles won for another.

My title: Queens of the court

replies.comment info:
HI, @James Bond --

Love that headline -- "Queens of the Court."

You write, "I wonder if these women ever competed in the same tournament against each other which would create a plateau for one line and an increase in titles won for another."  

ABSOLUTELY!  When you read the article that included this graph (which is released this afternoon), you will read about how champion players "seesawed" back and forth for titles.  This happened even more in men's singles.  

Great noticing and wonderings.

name: Sophie and Rosy
comment info:
Exhibition of Growth Graphs (EGG, derived from the tennis term "love" which means "egg" in French) 
All of the players begin around the same age, and they all retired around the same age. Serena Williams is an outlier, she is still active in her career. All of the data shows positive slopes. This graph compares the success rate of different tennis players. Some of the lines have plateaus, showing that there were some years in which they did not improve. However, Serena Williams has a relatively constant rate of increase. What is the comparison between each of the players' rates of change.

name: Maggie and Rylee
comment info:
All of the female tennis players showed an increasing amount of Grand Slam Title victories as they got older. The graph is telling us the progress these tennis players have made beginning as early as age 13. 

Steffi Graf was the most successful athlete at age 20 and then again at age 25. She is the youngest athlete, however she has the third most Grand Slam Titles. 

Margaret Court has the most Grand Slam Titles at age 31. She also had a 2-3 year stretch until age 25 where she does not win any titles. 

After looking at the graph, we wonder what factors would cause certain athletes to fall behind the others. For example, would injury play a role that cannot be seen from the graph itself?

Professional Women's Tennis Grand Slam Titles at Ages

name: SGCS
comment info:
6th period Geometry
Catchy headlines - 1. CWTPACW! (Comparing women tennis players' age and championships won)
2. Grand Slam titles held by women's tennis stars compared to their age!

What we notice?
We noticed that Serena Williams is the oldest player on the graph. We noticed that the lines cut off at a certain point. We noticed that is only contains five women players. We noticed they all have won 18 or more grand slams. 

What we wonder?
We wonder if these are the best women tennis players in the world. We wonder when they won each victory and the timing of the graph. We wonder what the points at the end of the lines mean. We wonder which of these tennis players currently play.

Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.

Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

name: Sharon
comment info:
Many responses have said that there is a correlation between the age of the champion and the number of Grand Slam titles won.  Two comments on this noticing.

Take another look at what is plotted on the y-axis.  With the lines always increasing (positive slope), could this be the number of titles earned by age?  Or, is it something else?  (Notice: Spoiler below.)

In statistics, correlation is only used when the relationship of two quantitative variables is linear -- that is, the graph of the points is generally in a line and not scattered or some other pattern, including curved.  If the points have some other pattern, then the variables are associated, but not correlated.  And, if they are scattered, there is no association.

So, in the Grand Slam graph, are the variables of age and cumulative number of Grand Slam titles correlated or associated?

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Group 3 --

You noticed that the older the champion is the more grand slams you have.  Does that mean that every year, players win more titles than the previous year?  Make sense?  So, what is being recorded on the y-axis?  It’s the cumulative total of Grand Slam titles in the player’s career.  That’s why the line never goes down.  For example, Margaret Court won 13 titles by the time she was 23 years old.  So, what does it mean when the line is horizontal?  

With a little effort, you could make another graph that shows the number of titles at each age for each player.  That may make it clearer at what age champions win the most titles.

comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

name: Chris C
comment info:
I notice that the slope of the graphs tend to be greater during the middle ages in the graph: this makes sense, as tennis players would probably win more titles during their prime years of around their 20s, and then as they get older, their bodies go through wear and tear and probably cannot win as many titles as their younger competition gets to beat them. Likewise, the slopes on the graphs are lower when they're younger because they're less experienced and perhaps not fully developed physically to compete with the athletes in their prime just yet. 

I wonder why the lines in the graphs differ in terms of when they stop in their age. I imagine this is because of the age differences of when they started vs when they retired, but wouldn't it make more sense to have it cut off all at once to make things easier to compare? 

Title: Age vs Number of Grand Slam Titles Won

Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who saw Margaret Court win the U.S. Open, and Kathy Dickensheets of Pittsburgh, who is looking forward to seeing if Serena can slam her way into history by winning more Grand Slam titles.

name: Moderator Kathy
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

name: Chris C
comment info:
I notice that the slope of the graphs tend to be greater during the middle ages in the graph: this makes sense, as tennis players would probably win more titles during their prime years of around their 20s, and then as they get older, their bodies go through wear and tear and probably cannot win as many titles as their younger competition gets to beat them. name: Sharon
comment info:
Many responses have said that there is a correlation between the age of the champion and the number of Grand Slam titles won.  Two comments on this noticing.

Take another look at what is plotted on the y-axis.  With the lines always increasing (positive slope), could this be the number of titles earned by age?  Or, is it something else?  (Notice: Spoiler below.)

In statistics, correlation is only used when the relationship of two quantitative variables is linear -- that is, the graph of the points is generally in a line and not scattered or some other pattern, including curved.  If the points have some other pattern, then the variables are associated, but not correlated.  And, if they are scattered, there is no association.

So, in the Grand Slam graph, are the variables of age and cumulative number of Grand Slam titles correlated or associated?

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Group 3 --

You noticed that the older the champion is the more grand slams you have.  Does that mean that every year, players win more titles than the previous year?  Make sense?  So, what is being recorded on the y-axis?  It’s the cumulative total of Grand Slam titles in the player’s career.  That’s why the line never goes down.  For example, Margaret Court won 13 titles by the time she was 23 years old.  So, what does it mean when the line is horizontal?  

With a little effort, you could make another graph that shows the number of titles at each age for each player.  That may make it clearer at what age champions win the most titles.

name: Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of  “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graph shows the cumulative sum of Grand Slam women’s singles titles by the age of the champion.  Tournaments that qualify for a Grand Slam title are the Australian, French, Wimbledon (English), and U.S. Opens.

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and  "What's going on in this graph?"  

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas about the graph. 

On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included this graph and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

The next “What’s Going On in This Graph?” will be released tomorrow -- Thursday, September 12 with moderation on Wednesday, September 18.  The topic – the changing U. S. population.

Thanks to all students who responded. name: Moderator Kathy
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who saw Margaret Court win the U.S. Open, and Kathy Dickensheets of Pittsburgh, who is looking forward to seeing if Serena can slam her way into history by winning more Grand Slam titles.

comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.

name: Maggie and Rylee
comment info:
All of the female tennis players showed an increasing amount of Grand Slam Title victories as they got older. The graph is telling us the progress these tennis players have made beginning as early as age 13. 

Steffi Graf was the most successful athlete at age 20 and then again at age 25. She is the youngest athlete, however she has the third most Grand Slam Titles. 

Margaret Court has the most Grand Slam Titles at age 31. She also had a 2-3 year stretch until age 25 where she does not win any titles. 

After looking at the graph, we wonder what factors would cause certain athletes to fall behind the others. For example, would injury play a role that cannot be seen from the graph itself?

Professional Women's Tennis Grand Slam Titles at Ages

name: SGCS
comment info:
6th period Geometry
Catchy headlines - 1. CWTPACW! (Comparing women tennis players' age and championships won)
2. Grand Slam titles held by women's tennis stars compared to their age!

What we notice?
We noticed that Serena Williams is the oldest player on the graph. We noticed that the lines cut off at a certain point. We noticed that is only contains five women players. We noticed they all have won 18 or more grand slams. 

What we wonder?
We wonder if these are the best women tennis players in the world. We wonder when they won each victory and the timing of the graph. We wonder what the points at the end of the lines mean. We wonder which of these tennis players currently play.

name: Chris C
comment info:
I notice that the slope of the graphs tend to be greater during the middle ages in the graph: this makes sense, as tennis players would probably win more titles during their prime years of around their 20s, and then as they get older, their bodies go through wear and tear and probably cannot win as many titles as their younger competition gets to beat them. Likewise, the slopes on the graphs are lower when they're younger because they're less experienced and perhaps not fully developed physically to compete with the athletes in their prime just yet. 

I wonder why the lines in the graphs differ in terms of when they stop in their age. I imagine this is because of the age differences of when they started vs when they retired, but wouldn't it make more sense to have it cut off all at once to make things easier to compare? 

Title: Age vs Number of Grand Slam Titles Won

comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

name: Moderator Kathy
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

name: Chris C
comment info:
I notice that the slope of the graphs tend to be greater during the middle ages in the graph: this makes sense, as tennis players would probably win more titles during their prime years of around their 20s, and then as they get older, their bodies go through wear and tear and probably cannot win as many titles as their younger competition gets to beat them. Likewise, the slopes on the graphs are lower when they're younger because they're less experienced and perhaps not fully developed physically to compete with the athletes in their prime just yet.

name: Sharon
comment info:
Many responses have said that there is a correlation between the age of the champion and the number of Grand Slam titles won.  Two comments on this noticing.

Take another look at what is plotted on the y-axis.  With the lines always increasing (positive slope), could this be the number of titles earned by age?  Or, is it something else?  (Notice: Spoiler below.)

In statistics, correlation is only used when the relationship of two quantitative variables is linear -- that is, the graph of the points is generally in a line and not scattered or some other pattern, including curved.  If the points have some other pattern, then the variables are associated, but not correlated.  And, if they are scattered, there is no association.

So, in the Grand Slam graph, are the variables of age and cumulative number of Grand Slam titles correlated or associated?

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Group 3 --

You noticed that the older the champion is the more grand slams you have.  Does that mean that every year, players win more titles than the previous year?  Make sense?  So, what is being recorded on the y-axis?  It’s the cumulative total of Grand Slam titles in the player’s career.  That’s why the line never goes down.  For example, Margaret Court won 13 titles by the time she was 23 years old.  So, what does it mean when the line is horizontal?  

With a little effort, you could make another graph that shows the number of titles at each age for each player.  That may make it clearer at what age champions win the most titles.

name: Moderator Kathy
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who saw Margaret Court win the U.S. Open, and Kathy Dickensheets of Pittsburgh, who is looking forward to seeing if Serena can slam her way into history by winning more Grand Slam titles.

Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

name: Moderator Kathy
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who saw Margaret Court win the U.S. Open, and Kathy Dickensheets of Pittsburgh, who is looking forward to seeing if Serena can slam her way into history by winning more Grand Slam titles.

name: Moderator Kathy
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who saw Margaret Court win the U.S. Open, and Kathy Dickensheets of Pittsburgh, who is looking forward to seeing if Serena can slam her way into history by winning more Grand Slam titles.

We think the graph is telling us that regardless of age, individuals can succeed in an intense setting. However, we also can recognize that age can be a hindrance to one's athletic career, seen by the decline in winnings by some, but not all, of the older athletes. 

We are still curious about how age plays a role in athletes' success because some of the competitors seem to be affected by it while others do not. Is there a difference in their preparation?

"Is Age a Factor? Not for these Grand Slam Winners."

name: Moderator Kathy
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who saw Margaret Court win the U.S. Open, and Kathy Dickensheets of Pittsburgh, who is looking forward to seeing if Serena can slam her way into history by winning more Grand Slam titles.

name: Moderator Kathy
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

replies.comment info:
HI, @James Bond --

Love that headline -- "Queens of the Court."

You write, "I wonder if these women ever competed in the same tournament against each other which would create a plateau for one line and an increase in titles won for another."  

ABSOLUTELY!  When you read the article that included this graph (which is released this afternoon), you will read about how champion players "seesawed" back and forth for titles.  This happened even more in men's singles.  

Great noticing and wonderings.

name: Sophie and Rosy
comment info:
Exhibition of Growth Graphs (EGG, derived from the tennis term "love" which means "egg" in French) 
All of the players begin around the same age, and they all retired around the same age. Serena Williams is an outlier, she is still active in her career. All of the data shows positive slopes. This graph compares the success rate of different tennis players. Some of the lines have plateaus, showing that there were some years in which they did not improve. However, Serena Williams has a relatively constant rate of increase. What is the comparison between each of the players' rates of change.

6th period Geometry

comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

name: Chris C
comment info:
I notice that the slope of the graphs tend to be greater during the middle ages in the graph: this makes sense, as tennis players would probably win more titles during their prime years of around their 20s, and then as they get older, their bodies go through wear and tear and probably cannot win as many titles as their younger competition gets to beat them. Likewise, the slopes on the graphs are lower when they're younger because they're less experienced and perhaps not fully developed physically to compete with the athletes in their prime just yet. 

I wonder why the lines in the graphs differ in terms of when they stop in their age. I imagine this is because of the age differences of when they started vs when they retired, but wouldn't it make more sense to have it cut off all at once to make things easier to compare? 

Title: Age vs Number of Grand Slam Titles Won

name: Sharon
comment info:
Many responses have said that there is a correlation between the age of the champion and the number of Grand Slam titles won.  Two comments on this noticing.

Take another look at what is plotted on the y-axis.  With the lines always increasing (positive slope), could this be the number of titles earned by age?  Or, is it something else?  (Notice: Spoiler below.)

In statistics, correlation is only used when the relationship of two quantitative variables is linear -- that is, the graph of the points is generally in a line and not scattered or some other pattern, including curved.  If the points have some other pattern, then the variables are associated, but not correlated.  And, if they are scattered, there is no association.

So, in the Grand Slam graph, are the variables of age and cumulative number of Grand Slam titles correlated or associated?

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Group 3 --

You noticed that the older the champion is the more grand slams you have.  Does that mean that every year, players win more titles than the previous year?  Make sense?  So, what is being recorded on the y-axis?  It’s the cumulative total of Grand Slam titles in the player’s career.  That’s why the line never goes down.  For example, Margaret Court won 13 titles by the time she was 23 years old.  So, what does it mean when the line is horizontal?  

With a little effort, you could make another graph that shows the number of titles at each age for each player.  That may make it clearer at what age champions win the most titles.

name: Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of  “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graph shows the cumulative sum of Grand Slam women’s singles titles by the age of the champion.  Tournaments that qualify for a Grand Slam title are the Australian, French, Wimbledon (English), and U.S. Opens.

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and  "What's going on in this graph?"  

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas about the graph. 

On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included this graph and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

The next “What’s Going On in This Graph?” will be released tomorrow -- Thursday, September 12 with moderation on Wednesday, September 18.  The topic – the changing U. S. population.

name: Moderator Kathy
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who saw Margaret Court win the U.S. Open, and Kathy Dickensheets of Pittsburgh, who is looking forward to seeing if Serena can slam her way into history by winning more Grand Slam titles.

Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who saw Margaret Court win the U.S. Open, and Kathy Dickensheets of Pittsburgh, who is looking forward to seeing if Serena can slam her way into history by winning more Grand Slam titles.

name: Moderator Kathy
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

name: Julie D.
comment info: I wonder what this graph means, and what its true purpose is. We decided that, based off of what we observed, a good title for the graph would be "Grand Slam Title and Age: Do they Correlate?"

name: Sean F
comment info: This graph mostly explores the rate at which the titles are earned, rather than the amount. As the players age, they earn more titles, and it's likely that no player would lose a grand slam title as they get older. It's a fair assumption that each player will increase in titles as they get older- the question is, how quickly? And when do they start? Ultimately, I feel the graph is comparing the rate in which these players earned their titles, and adopts the line graph for added information as to the age the award was received.

name: Chris C
comment info:
I notice that the slope of the graphs tend to be greater during the middle ages in the graph: this makes sense, as tennis players would probably win more titles during their prime years of around their 20s, and then as they get older, their bodies go through wear and tear and probably cannot win as many titles as their younger competition gets to beat them. Likewise, the slopes on the graphs are lower when they're younger because they're less experienced and perhaps not fully developed physically to compete with the athletes in their prime just yet. 

I wonder why the lines in the graphs differ in terms of when they stop in their age. I imagine this is because of the age differences of when they started vs when they retired, but wouldn't it make more sense to have it cut off all at once to make things easier to compare? 

Title: Age vs Number of Grand Slam Titles Won

comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.

Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

name: Moderator Kathy
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who saw Margaret Court win the U.S. Open, and Kathy Dickensheets of Pittsburgh, who is looking forward to seeing if Serena can slam her way into history by winning more Grand Slam titles.

name: Moderator Kathy
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who saw Margaret Court win the U.S. Open, and Kathy Dickensheets of Pittsburgh, who is looking forward to seeing if Serena can slam her way into history by winning more Grand Slam titles.

comment info:
Many responses have said that there is a correlation between the age of the champion and the number of Grand Slam titles won.  Two comments on this noticing.

Take another look at what is plotted on the y-axis.  With the lines always increasing (positive slope), could this be the number of titles earned by age?  Or, is it something else?  (Notice: Spoiler below.)

In statistics, correlation is only used when the relationship of two quantitative variables is linear -- that is, the graph of the points is generally in a line and not scattered or some other pattern, including curved.  If the points have some other pattern, then the variables are associated, but not correlated.  And, if they are scattered, there is no association.

So, in the Grand Slam graph, are the variables of age and cumulative number of Grand Slam titles correlated or associated?

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Group 3 --

You noticed that the older the champion is the more grand slams you have.  Does that mean that every year, players win more titles than the previous year?  Make sense?  So, what is being recorded on the y-axis?  It’s the cumulative total of Grand Slam titles in the player’s career.  That’s why the line never goes down.  For example, Margaret Court won 13 titles by the time she was 23 years old.  So, what does it mean when the line is horizontal?  

With a little effort, you could make another graph that shows the number of titles at each age for each player.  That may make it clearer at what age champions win the most titles.

name: Moderator Kathy
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who saw Margaret Court win the U.S. Open, and Kathy Dickensheets of Pittsburgh, who is looking forward to seeing if Serena can slam her way into history by winning more Grand Slam titles.

comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

name: Chris C
comment info:
I notice that the slope of the graphs tend to be greater during the middle ages in the graph: this makes sense, as tennis players would probably win more titles during their prime years of around their 20s, and then as they get older, their bodies go through wear and tear and probably cannot win as many titles as their younger competition gets to beat them. Likewise, the slopes on the graphs are lower when they're younger because they're less experienced and perhaps not fully developed physically to compete with the athletes in their prime just yet. 

I wonder why the lines in the graphs differ in terms of when they stop in their age. I imagine this is because of the age differences of when they started vs when they retired, but wouldn't it make more sense to have it cut off all at once to make things easier to compare? 

Title: Age vs Number of Grand Slam Titles Won

name: Moderator Kathy
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

name: Sean F
comment info: This graph mostly explores the rate at which the titles are earned, rather than the amount. As the players age, they earn more titles, and it's likely that no player would lose a grand slam title as they get older. It's a fair assumption that each player will increase in titles as they get older- the question is, how quickly? And when do they start? Ultimately, I feel the graph is comparing the rate in which these players earned their titles, and adopts the line graph for added information as to the age the award was received.

name: Moderator Kathy
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who saw Margaret Court win the U.S. Open, and Kathy Dickensheets of Pittsburgh, who is looking forward to seeing if Serena can slam her way into history by winning more Grand Slam titles.

Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

name: Sharon
comment info:
Many responses have said that there is a correlation between the age of the champion and the number of Grand Slam titles won.  Two comments on this noticing.

Take another look at what is plotted on the y-axis.  With the lines always increasing (positive slope), could this be the number of titles earned by age?  Or, is it something else?  (Notice: Spoiler below.)

In statistics, correlation is only used when the relationship of two quantitative variables is linear -- that is, the graph of the points is generally in a line and not scattered or some other pattern, including curved.  If the points have some other pattern, then the variables are associated, but not correlated.  And, if they are scattered, there is no association.

So, in the Grand Slam graph, are the variables of age and cumulative number of Grand Slam titles correlated or associated?

comment info:
What do you notice? there is six tennis players on the graph. We also noticed that the higher the age the more grand slams you have.

What do you wonder? Why are the lines not straight?

What’s going on in this graph? Age don't matter!

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Group 3 --

You noticed that the older the champion is the more grand slams you have.  Does that mean that every year, players win more titles than the previous year?  Make sense?  So, what is being recorded on the y-axis?  It’s the cumulative total of Grand Slam titles in the player’s career.  That’s why the line never goes down.  For example, Margaret Court won 13 titles by the time she was 23 years old.  So, what does it mean when the line is horizontal?  

With a little effort, you could make another graph that shows the number of titles at each age for each player.  That may make it clearer at what age champions win the most titles.

name: Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of  “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graph shows the cumulative sum of Grand Slam women’s singles titles by the age of the champion.  Tournaments that qualify for a Grand Slam title are the Australian, French, Wimbledon (English), and U.S. Opens.

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and  "What's going on in this graph?"  

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas about the graph. 

On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included this graph and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

The next “What’s Going On in This Graph?” will be released tomorrow -- Thursday, September 12 with moderation on Wednesday, September 18.  The topic – the changing U. S. population.

name: Moderator Kathy
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who saw Margaret Court win the U.S. Open, and Kathy Dickensheets of Pittsburgh, who is looking forward to seeing if Serena can slam her way into history by winning more Grand Slam titles.

name: Moderator Kathy
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

replies.comment info:
HI, @James Bond --

Love that headline -- "Queens of the Court."

You write, "I wonder if these women ever competed in the same tournament against each other which would create a plateau for one line and an increase in titles won for another."  

ABSOLUTELY!  When you read the article that included this graph (which is released this afternoon), you will read about how champion players "seesawed" back and forth for titles.  This happened even more in men's singles.  

Great noticing and wonderings.

name: Sophie and Rosy
comment info:
Exhibition of Growth Graphs (EGG, derived from the tennis term "love" which means "egg" in French) 
All of the players begin around the same age, and they all retired around the same age. Serena Williams is an outlier, she is still active in her career. All of the data shows positive slopes. This graph compares the success rate of different tennis players. Some of the lines have plateaus, showing that there were some years in which they did not improve. However, Serena Williams has a relatively constant rate of increase. What is the comparison between each of the players' rates of change.

6th period Geometry

comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

name: Chris C
comment info:
I notice that the slope of the graphs tend to be greater during the middle ages in the graph: this makes sense, as tennis players would probably win more titles during their prime years of around their 20s, and then as they get older, their bodies go through wear and tear and probably cannot win as many titles as their younger competition gets to beat them. Likewise, the slopes on the graphs are lower when they're younger because they're less experienced and perhaps not fully developed physically to compete with the athletes in their prime just yet. 

I wonder why the lines in the graphs differ in terms of when they stop in their age. I imagine this is because of the age differences of when they started vs when they retired, but wouldn't it make more sense to have it cut off all at once to make things easier to compare? 

Title: Age vs Number of Grand Slam Titles Won

name: Sharon
comment info:
Many responses have said that there is a correlation between the age of the champion and the number of Grand Slam titles won.  Two comments on this noticing.

Take another look at what is plotted on the y-axis.  With the lines always increasing (positive slope), could this be the number of titles earned by age?  Or, is it something else?  (Notice: Spoiler below.)

In statistics, correlation is only used when the relationship of two quantitative variables is linear -- that is, the graph of the points is generally in a line and not scattered or some other pattern, including curved.  If the points have some other pattern, then the variables are associated, but not correlated.  And, if they are scattered, there is no association.

So, in the Grand Slam graph, are the variables of age and cumulative number of Grand Slam titles correlated or associated?

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Group 3 --

You noticed that the older the champion is the more grand slams you have.  Does that mean that every year, players win more titles than the previous year?  Make sense?  So, what is being recorded on the y-axis?  It’s the cumulative total of Grand Slam titles in the player’s career.  That’s why the line never goes down.  For example, Margaret Court won 13 titles by the time she was 23 years old.  So, what does it mean when the line is horizontal?

name: Moderator Kathy
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.  

Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who saw Margaret Court win the U.S. Open, and Kathy Dickensheets of Pittsburgh, who is looking forward to seeing if Serena can slam her way into history by winning more Grand Slam titles.

Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

My partner and I notice that Margaret Court has won more Grand Slam titles than Serena Williams when they were both in their early 30's. Steffi Graf is also the youngest, but has a competitive number of Grand Slam titles with the older players. Martina Navratilova, from 25-30, continuously won titles but has plateaued with her winnings. 

We think the graph is telling us that regardless of age, individuals can succeed in an intense setting. However, we also can recognize that age can be a hindrance to one's athletic career, seen by the decline in winnings by some, but not all, of the older athletes. 

We are still curious about how age plays a role in athletes' success because some of the competitors seem to be affected by it while others do not. Is there a difference in their preparation?

"Is Age a Factor? Not for these Grand Slam Winners."

name: James Bond
comment info:
I notice that Steffetti qualified for a Grand Slam Tournament at only thirteen which is an impressive feat. I wonder if these women ever competed in the same tournament against each other which would create a plateau for one line and an increase in titles won for another.

My title: Queens of the court

replies.comment info:
HI, @James Bond --

Love that headline -- "Queens of the Court."

You write, "I wonder if these women ever competed in the same tournament against each other which would create a plateau for one line and an increase in titles won for another."  

ABSOLUTELY!  When you read the article that included this graph (which is released this afternoon), you will read about how champion players "seesawed" back and forth for titles.  This happened even more in men's singles.  

Great noticing and wonderings.

name: Sophie and Rosy
comment info:
Exhibition of Growth Graphs (EGG, derived from the tennis term "love" which means "egg" in French) 
All of the players begin around the same age, and they all retired around the same age. Serena Williams is an outlier, she is still active in her career. All of the data shows positive slopes. This graph compares the success rate of different tennis players. Some of the lines have plateaus, showing that there were some years in which they did not improve. However, Serena Williams has a relatively constant rate of increase. What is the comparison between each of the players' rates of change.

name: Maggie and Rylee
comment info:
All of the female tennis players showed an increasing amount of Grand Slam Title victories as they got older. The graph is telling us the progress these tennis players have made beginning as early as age 13. 

Steffi Graf was the most successful athlete at age 20 and then again at age 25. She is the youngest athlete, however she has the third most Grand Slam Titles. 

Margaret Court has the most Grand Slam Titles at age 31. She also had a 2-3 year stretch until age 25 where she does not win any titles. 

After looking at the graph, we wonder what factors would cause certain athletes to fall behind the others. For example, would injury play a role that cannot be seen from the graph itself?

Professional Women's Tennis Grand Slam Titles at Ages

name: SGCS
comment info:
6th period Geometry
Catchy headlines - 1. CWTPACW! (Comparing women tennis players' age and championships won)
2. Grand Slam titles held by women's tennis stars compared to their age!

What we notice?
We noticed that Serena Williams is the oldest player on the graph. We noticed that the lines cut off at a certain point. We noticed that is only contains five women players. We noticed they all have won 18 or more grand slams. 

What we wonder?
We wonder if these are the best women tennis players in the world. We wonder when they won each victory and the timing of the graph. We wonder what the points at the end of the lines mean. We wonder which of these tennis players currently play.

Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and three Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?”   the topic – the changing U.S. population.

Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph: "Senior Serena Still Swinging at Success: by Shannon of Hampton, PA; "Love for Tennis Champs: Their successes through the years" by Kingsbury 1st period Minnesota, US; and "Slamming into History" by Raquel of East Texas.

name: Sharon
comment info:
Many responses have said that there is a correlation between the age of the champion and the number of Grand Slam titles won.  Two comments on this noticing.

Take another look at what is plotted on the y-axis.  With the lines always increasing (positive slope), could this be the number of titles earned by age?  Or, is it something else?  (Notice: Spoiler below.)

In statistics, correlation is only used when the relationship of two quantitative variables is linear -- that is, the graph of the points is generally in a line and not scattered or some other pattern, including curved.  If the points have some other pattern, then the variables are associated, but not correlated.  And, if they are scattered, there is no association.

So, in the Grand Slam graph, are the variables of age and cumulative number of Grand Slam titles correlated or associated?

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Group 3 --

You noticed that the older the champion is the more grand slams you have.  Does that mean that every year, players win more titles than the previous year?  Make sense?  So, what is being recorded on the y-axis?  It’s the cumulative total of Grand Slam titles in the player’s career.  That’s why the line never goes down.  For example, Margaret Court won 13 titles by the time she was 23 years old.  So, what does it mean when the line is horizontal?  

With a little effort, you could make another graph that shows the number of titles at each age for each player.  That may make it clearer at what age champions win the most titles.

name: Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of  “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graph shows the cumulative sum of Grand Slam women’s singles titles by the age of the champion.  Tournaments that qualify for a Grand Slam title are the Australian, French, Wimbledon (English), and U.S. Opens.

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and  "What's going on in this graph?"  

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas about the graph. 

On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included this graph and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

The next “What’s Going On in This Graph?” will be released tomorrow -- Thursday, September 12 with moderation on Wednesday, September 18.  The topic – the changing U. S. population.
